required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of FGM on Glucose Control in Diabetic Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of FGM on Glucose Control in Diabetic Patients

lead_sponsor.agency: Nanjing First Hospital, Nanjing Medical University

clinical_study.source: Nanjing First Hospital, Nanjing Medical University

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of the study is to assess the eﬀect of FGM on glycemic control compared with SMBG using a randomised controlled study design in adults with type 2 diabetes.

detailed_description.textblock: Flash glucose monitoring (FGM) is a newly introduced Glucose Monitoring system. The aim of the study is to assess the eﬀect of FGM on glycemic control compared with standard blood glucose monitoring (SMBG) using a randomised controlled study design in adults with type 2 diabetes. Subjects will use unmasked FGM once a month or SMBG to monitor glucose level for 3 months. Patients in the SMBG group will wear masked FGM to collect glycaemic variability data for comparison to the intervention group of the study. The primary outcome, HbA1c, will be cpmpared at baseline and 3 month. Glucose control parameters provided by unmasked and masked FGM will be compared in the two groups, including mean blood glucose (MBG), coefficient of variation (CV), area under the curve (AUC), Time in Range(TIR), etc.

primary_outcome.description: Difference in HbA1c between intervention and control group at 3 month adjusting for baseline HbA1c

secondary_outcome.description: Difference in HbA1c between intervention and control group at 1, 2, and 3 month.
Difference in CV between intervention and control group at 1, 2, and 3 month.
Difference in AUC<3.9mmol/L and >10mmol/L between intervention and control group at 1, 2, and 3 month.
Difference in time in range 3.9-10 mmol/L between intervention and control group at 1, 2, and 3 month.
Accuracy of FGM values versus reference blood glucose values (Consensus Error Grid (CEG) analysis and calculation of the Mean Absolute Relative Difference (MARD)

arm_group.description: Diabetic patients will use FreeStyle Libre Flash Glucose Monitoring (FGM) system(unmasked) to monitor glucose level once a month for 3 months.

Diabetic patients will use Standard Blood Glucose Monitoring (SMBG) to monitor glucose level for 3 months. A 14-day masked wear of FreeStyle Libre H Flash Glucose Monitoring system is included for these subjects once a month, to collect glycaemic variability data for comparison to the intervention group of the study.

intervention.description: Freestyle Libre Flash Glucose Monitoring will be used in diabetic patients once a month for therr months to monitor glucose level. Patients could scan the sensor to get the glucose level at any time as they want. They could alter thier diet and exercise according to the glucose levels. Patients will be required to keep track of food and exercise during wearing FGM sensor. Physicians would adjust patients' medication according their glucose profile provided by FGM, A1c, and diet and exercise every month.

overall_official.affiliation: The First Affiliated Hospital with Nanjing Medical University
